item.title: Sabina Nessa: Hundreds pay respects at London vigil
item.description: The vigil at Pegler Square is not far from where a wanted suspect was captured on CCTV.

item.title: Petrol driver shortage: Ministers discuss supply issues
item.description: Ministers focused on the impact of the lorry driver shortage, with fuel the latest sector to be affected.

item.title: Olly Stephens: Three teenagers detained over boy's stabbing death
item.description: Olly Stephens, 13, was ambushed by two boys after being lured to a field by a girl in Reading.

item.title: Huawei's Meng Wanzhou to be freed in US deal
item.description: Chief financial officer Meng Wanzhou has been detained in Canada over US fraud charges since 2018.

item.title: Raducanu takes on Duchess of Cambridge
item.description: US Open champion Emma Raducanu says she was "more nervous playing the Duchess of Cambridge" before her Homecoming Party than during the US Open final.

item.title: Covid-19: Ministers meet over petrol supplies and hotspot schools bring back masks
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Friday evening.

item.title: Margaret Keenan: First UK person to get the Pfizer jab gets booster
item.description: The 91-year-old got her booster in Coventry alongside the matron who administered her first dose.

item.title: Doctor Who: Russell T Davies returns as programme showrunner
item.description: The It's A Sin writer says he is "beyond excited" to resume the role he filled from 2005 to 2009.

item.title: Afghanistan: Executions will return, says senior Taliban official
item.description: Extreme punishments like executions and amputations will resume in Afghanistan, says the Taliban's head of prisons.

item.title: CBD trial to treat hallucinations in Parkinson’s disease
item.description: Charles Ogilvie-Forbes is a volunteer in a clinical trial at King’s College Hospital, London.

item.title: Boris Johnson and Macron speak after military pact row
item.description: UK and France will work together despite a diplomatic spat over Australian submarines, Downing Street says.

item.title: Airport arrivals hit by passport gate failure
item.description: Passengers arriving at UK airports suffer delays after an IT problem hits self-service passport gates.

item.title: Migrants freezing to death on Belarus-Poland border
item.description: The BBC finds stranded migrants facing sub-zero temperatures amid a row between Poland and Belarus.

item.title: Mozambique militant attacks: 'So much destruction'
item.description: The BBC's Anne Soy sees how Islamic militants have terrorised Cabo Delgado in northern Mozambique

item.title: Mondelez threatens trademark battle over bar's lilac packaging
item.description: Mondelez believes Primal Pantry's vegan fruit bar "exploits" the trademark of its Milka chocolates.

item.title: Northumberland diver finds seal with ring stuck round neck
item.description: A seal is found swimming off the Northumberland coast with a rubber ring stuck around its neck.

item.title: Homeless in London: 'People pretend they are not there'
item.description: Photographer Anthony Dawton has been documenting London's homeless population during the pandemic.

item.title: Strictly's Rose Ayling-Ellis rehearsing without hearing music
item.description: Rose Ayling-Ellis and her dance partner Giovanni Pernice prepare for their first live performance.

item.title: The Papers: Fuel shortage warning and Sussex and the City
item.description: The arrest of a man on suspicion of the murder of Sabina Nessa also makes many of Friday's front pages.

item.title: The Magic Circle appoints its youngest, and first female, president
item.description: Megan Swann, who does "environmental magic" is now the most senior magician in the UK.

item.title: Man's hidden Hornby model railway collection fetches £21k
item.description: Adrian Batty's wife says she had no idea her late husband had amassed hundreds of rare models.

item.title: Sabina Nessa killing: Does following the 'rules' keep women safe?
item.description: Safety tips for women continue to suggest murderers have an excuse for killing.

item.title: Olly Stephens' parents recall 'horror' of day he was murdered
item.description: Stuart and Amanda Stephens describe finding their "lifeless" son after he was fatally stabbed.

item.title: 'How we re-delivered a baby's postcard - 75 years on'
item.description: After an illness, Stu began reuniting old postcards with their owners - and revived some buried memories.

item.title: What is fat freezing and what are the risks?
item.description: A non-surgical technique to remove stubborn fat from the body can have side effects.

item.title: Mario: Can Chris Pratt help Nintendo solve the puzzle of video game films?
item.description: Game-to-film adaptations have a chequered history - can Chris Pratt solve the industry puzzle?

item.title: LGBT freshers: 'I worried Oxford wouldn't accept me'
item.description: New LGBT students share their hopes and concerns as analysis reveals the extra challenges they face.

item.title: German elections 2021: The conspiracy theories targeting voters
item.description: One wildly inaccurate claim suggests Germany does not actually exist.

item.title: Singapore migrant workers are still living in Covid lockdown
item.description: The workers in Singapore are enduring one of the longest Covid confinement periods in the world.

item.title: Gas crisis leaves Europe searching for solutions
item.description: Consumers face a steep rise in energy bills as governments try to fund the move to renewable energy.

item.title: Keir Starmer is taking a big risk
item.description: As Labour conference approaches, Sir Keir Starmer intends to take the fight to his critics inside the party.

item.title: US dominate Europe in first session at Whistling Straits
item.description: Jon Rahm and Sergio Garcia strike first for Europe but the US win three of the four foursomes matches and lead 3-1 after the opening session of the Ryder Cup.

item.title: County Championship: Warwickshire beat Somerset to win first title since 2012
item.description: Warwickshire beat Somerset at Edgbaston to win their first County Championship title in nine years.

item.title: 'It's been a journey of learning' - Joshua 'comes in light' for Usyk fight
item.description: Anthony Joshua cuts a lean, powerful figure as he weighs in for Saturday's world heavyweight title defence against Oleksandr Usyk.

item.title: Emma Raducanu: British number one splits with coach after US Open win
item.description: British number one Emma Raducanu splits with the coach who helped guide her to a first Grand Slam title at the US Open.

item.title: Ryder Cup: 'One of the greatest shots you'll see from Spieth'
item.description: Watch Jordan Spieth hit an incredible shot up a vertical bank on day one of the Ryder Cup at Whistling Straits in Wisconsin.

item.title: What can I do if my energy supplier goes bust?
item.description: Nearly 1.5 million customers have seen their energy firm collapse amid soaring gas prices.

item.title: Gas prices: Why are they so high and what is the energy price cap?
item.description: Householders face a rise in energy bills - as well as the possibility their supplier could go bust.

item.title: Where does the UK get its gas and is it facing a shortage this winter?
item.description: A surge in gas prices has prompted fears of hard times ahead - but how bad could it get?

item.title: Why is there a CO2 shortage and how will it hit food supplies?
item.description: The UK's food industry has been told it must pay five times more for carbon dioxide in future.

item.title: Gas prices: 'I'm just watching the meter go up'
item.description: Customers caught in the middle of the energy price crisis face higher bills but are told not to panic.

item.title: Covid: How can missing five million be persuaded to have the jab?
item.description: Headlines have focused on teenagers and booster doses - but millions still haven't had a first jab.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Travel update: What are the new rules for holidays in Europe and the US?
item.description: Eight countries have now moved from the UK's red travel lists, to the less restrictive amber.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: People in England could be told to work from home once again through the autumn and winter.

item.title: Flu jab 2021: Who’s eligible for a free vaccine?
item.description: This year's roll out has expanded in an attempt to shield against a double whammy of flu and Covid.

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'In my business, you eat what you kill'
item.description: Music executive Riki Bleau shares his business advice for our CEO Secrets series.

item.title: Ryder Cup: Tales behind Great Britain's wins over the United States
item.description: Britain only defeated the US three times in the first 25 Ryder Cups, but behind each victory is a wealth of remarkable stories.

item.title: The torso in the Thames: A 20-year mystery
item.description: Twenty years ago, a young African boy was murdered and his torso was dumped in the Thames. It's the longest unsolved child murder case in the recent history of the Metropolitan Police.

item.title: Paul Rusesabagina: From Hotel Rwanda hero to convicted terrorist
item.description: Paul Rusesabagina, who was portrayed in Hotel Rwanda, has gone from national hero to enemy of the state.

item.title: Fake Paralympians boss: 'I didn't know about cheating'
item.description: The man fined for sending non-disabled athletes to the Sydney Paralympics breaks his silence.
